title: George V
text:
George V (George Frederick Ernest Albert; 3 June 1865 – 20 January 1936) was <a href="King%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">King of the United Kingdom</a> and the <a href="British%20Dominions">British Dominions</a>, and <a href="Emperor%20of%20India">Emperor of India</a>, from 6 May 1910 until his death in 1936.
Born during the reign of his grandmother <a href="Queen%20Victoria">Queen Victoria</a>, George was the second son of <a href="Albert%20Edward%2C%20Prince%20of%20Wales">Albert Edward, Prince of Wales</a>, and was third in the line of <a href="succession%20to%20the%20British%20throne">succession to the British throne</a> behind his father and elder brother, <a href="Prince%20Albert%20Victor%2C%20Duke%20of%20Clarence%20and%20Avondale">Prince Albert Victor</a>. From 1877 to 1892, George served in the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a>, until the unexpected death of his elder brother in early 1892 put him directly in line for the throne. On Victoria's death in 1901, George's father ascended the throne as Edward VII, and George was created <a href="Prince%20of%20Wales">Prince of Wales</a>. He became <a href="king-emperor">king-emperor</a> on his father's death in 1910.
George's reign saw the rise of <a href="socialism">socialism</a>, <a href="communism">communism</a>, <a href="fascism">fascism</a>, <a href="Irish%20republicanism">Irish republicanism</a>, and the <a href="Indian%20independence%20movement">Indian independence movement</a>, all of which radically changed the political landscape of the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a>. The <a href="Parliament%20Act%201911">Parliament Act 1911</a> established the supremacy of the elected <a href="British%20House%20of%20Commons">British House of Commons</a> over the unelected <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a>. As a result of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> (1914–1918), the empires of his first cousins <a href="Nicholas%20II%20of%20Russia">Nicholas II of Russia</a> and <a href="Wilhelm%20II%20of%20Germany">Wilhelm II of Germany</a> fell, while the British Empire expanded to its greatest effective extent. In 1917, he became the first monarch of the <a href="House%20of%20Windsor">House of Windsor</a>, which he renamed from the <a href="House%20of%20Saxe-Coburg%20and%20Gotha">House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha</a> as a result of anti-German public sentiment. In 1924, George appointed the first <a href="Labour%20Party%20%28UK%29">Labour</a> <a href="First%20MacDonald%20ministry">ministry</a> and the <a href="Statute%20of%20Westminster%201931">1931 Statute of Westminster</a> recognised the Empire's dominions as separate, independent states within the <a href="British%20Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">British Commonwealth of Nations</a>.
He suffered from smoking-related health problems throughout much of his later reign, and at his death was succeeded by his eldest son, <a href="Edward%20VIII">Edward VIII</a>.
Early life and education.
George was born on 3 June 1865, in <a href="Marlborough%20House">Marlborough House</a>, London. He was the second son of <a href="Albert%20Edward%2C%20Prince%20of%20Wales">Albert Edward, Prince of Wales</a>, and <a href="Alexandra%2C%20Princess%20of%20Wales">Alexandra, Princess of Wales</a>. His father was the eldest son of <a href="Queen%20Victoria">Queen Victoria</a> and <a href="Albert%2C%20Prince%20Consort">Prince Albert</a>, and his mother was the eldest daughter of <a href="King%20Christian%20IX">King Christian IX</a> and <a href="Louise%20of%20Hesse-Kassel">Queen Louise of Denmark</a>. He was baptised at <a href="Windsor%20Castle">Windsor Castle</a> on 7 July 1865 by the <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Canterbury">Archbishop of Canterbury</a>, <a href="Charles%20Longley">Charles Longley</a>.
As a younger son of the Prince of Wales, there was little expectation that George would become king. He was third in line to the throne, after his father and elder brother, <a href="Prince%20Albert%20Victor">Prince Albert Victor</a>. George was only 17 months younger than Albert Victor, and the two princes were educated together. <a href="John%20Neale%20Dalton">John Neale Dalton</a> was appointed as their tutor in 1871. Neither Albert Victor nor George excelled intellectually. As their father thought that the navy was "the very best possible training for any boy", in September 1877, when George was 12 years old, both brothers joined the cadet training ship <a href="HMS%20Prince%20of%20Wales%20%281860%29">HMS "Britannia"</a> at <a href="Dartmouth%2C%20Devon">Dartmouth, Devon</a>.
For three years from 1879, the royal brothers served on , accompanied by Dalton. They toured the colonies of the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a> in the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, South Africa and Australia, and visited <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a>, as well as South America, the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a>, Egypt, and East Asia. In 1881 on a visit to Japan, George had a local artist tattoo a blue and red dragon on his arm, and was received in an audience by the <a href="Emperor%20Meiji">Emperor Meiji</a>; George and his brother presented <a href="Empress%20Haruko">Empress Haruko</a> with two <a href="wallabies">wallabies</a> from Australia. Dalton wrote an account of their journey entitled "The Cruise of HMS Bacchante". Between <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a> and <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>, Dalton recorded a sighting of the "<a href="Flying%20Dutchman">Flying Dutchman</a>", a mythical ghost ship. When they returned to Britain, the Queen complained that her grandsons could not speak <a href="French%20language">French</a> or <a href="German%20language">German</a>, and so they spent six months in <a href="Lausanne">Lausanne</a> in an ultimately unsuccessful attempt to learn another language. After Lausanne, the brothers were separated; Albert Victor attended <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Trinity College, Cambridge</a>, while George continued in the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a>. He travelled the world, visiting many areas of the British Empire. During his naval career he commanded "Torpedo Boat 79" in home waters, then on the <a href="North%20America%20and%20West%20Indies%20Station">North America and West Indies Station</a>. His last active service was in command of <a href="HMS%20Melampus%20%281890%29">HMS "Melampus"</a> in 1891–92. From then on, his naval rank was largely honorary.
Marriage.
As a young man destined to serve in the navy, Prince George served for many years under the command of his uncle, <a href="Prince%20Alfred%2C%20Duke%20of%20Edinburgh">Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh</a>, who was stationed in <a href="Malta">Malta</a>. There, he grew close to and fell in love with his cousin, <a href="Princess%20Marie%20of%20Edinburgh">Princess Marie of Edinburgh</a>. His grandmother, father and uncle all approved the match, but his mother and aunt—the Princess of Wales and <a href="Maria%20Alexandrovna%2C%20Duchess%20of%20Edinburgh">Maria Alexandrovna, Duchess of Edinburgh</a>—opposed it. The Princess of Wales thought the family was too pro-German, and the Duchess of Edinburgh disliked England. The Duchess, the only daughter of <a href="Alexander%20II%20of%20Russia">Alexander II of Russia</a>, resented the fact that, as the wife of a younger son of the British sovereign, she had to yield precedence to George's mother, the Princess of Wales, whose father had been a minor German prince before being called unexpectedly to the throne of Denmark. Guided by her mother, Marie refused George when he proposed to her. She married <a href="Ferdinand%20I%20of%20Romania">Ferdinand</a>, the future <a href="King%20of%20Romania">King of Romania</a>, in 1893.
In November 1891, George's elder brother, Albert Victor, became engaged to his <a href="second%20cousin%20once%20removed">second cousin once removed</a> <a href="Princess%20Victoria%20Mary%20of%20Teck">Princess Victoria Mary of Teck</a>, known as "May" within the family. Her parents were <a href="Francis%2C%20Duke%20of%20Teck">Francis, Duke of Teck</a> (a member of a <a href="morganatic">morganatic</a>, cadet branch of the <a href="House%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg">House of Württemberg</a>), and <a href="Princess%20Mary%20Adelaide%20of%20Cambridge">Princess Mary Adelaide of Cambridge</a>, a male-line granddaughter of <a href="King%20George%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BIII">King George III</a> and a first cousin of Queen Victoria.
On 14 January 1892, six weeks after the formal engagement, Albert Victor died of <a href="pneumonia">pneumonia</a> during an <a href="1889%E2%80%931890%20pandemic">influenza pandemic</a>, leaving George second in line to the throne, and likely to succeed after his father. George had only just recovered from a serious illness himself, after being confined to bed for six weeks with <a href="typhoid%20fever">typhoid fever</a>, the disease that was thought to have killed his grandfather Prince Albert. Queen Victoria still regarded Princess May as a suitable match for her grandson, and George and May grew close during their shared period of mourning.
A year after Albert Victor's death, George proposed to May and was accepted. They married on 6 July 1893 at the <a href="Chapel%20Royal">Chapel Royal</a> in <a href="St%20James%27s%20Palace">St James's Palace</a>, London. Throughout their lives, they remained devoted to each other. George was, on his own admission, unable to express his feelings easily in speech, but they often exchanged loving letters and notes of endearment.
Duke of York.
The death of his elder brother effectively ended George's naval career, as he was now second in line to the throne, after his father. George was created <a href="Duke%20of%20York">Duke of York</a>, <a href="Earl%20of%20Inverness">Earl of Inverness</a>, and <a href="Baron%20Killarney">Baron Killarney</a> by Queen Victoria on 24 May 1892, and received lessons in constitutional history from <a href="J.%20R.%20Tanner">J. R. Tanner</a>.
The Duke and Duchess of York had <a href="%23Issue">five sons and a daughter</a>. <a href="Randolph%20Churchill">Randolph Churchill</a> claimed that George was a strict father, to the extent that his children were terrified of him, and that George had remarked to the <a href="Edward%20Stanley%2C%2017th%20Earl%20of%20Derby">Earl of Derby</a>: "My father was frightened of his mother, I was frightened of my father, and I am damned well going to see to it that my children are frightened of me." In reality, there is no direct source for the quotation and it is likely that George's parenting style was little different from that adopted by most people at the time. Whether this was the case or not, his children did seem to resent his strict nature, <a href="Prince%20Henry%2C%20Duke%20of%20Gloucester">Prince Henry</a> going as far as to describe him as a "terrible father" in later years.
They lived mainly at <a href="York%20Cottage">York Cottage</a>, a relatively small house in <a href="Sandringham%2C%20Norfolk">Sandringham, Norfolk</a>, where their way of life mirrored that of a comfortable middle-class family rather than royalty. George preferred a simple, almost quiet, life, in marked contrast to the lively social life pursued by his father. His official biographer, <a href="Harold%20Nicolson">Harold Nicolson</a>, later despaired of George's time as Duke of York, writing: "He may be all right as a young midshipman and a wise old king, but when he was Duke of York ... he did nothing at all but kill ["i.e." shoot] animals and stick in stamps." George was an avid <a href="stamp%20collector">stamp collector</a>, which Nicolson disparaged, but George played a large role in building the <a href="Royal%20Philatelic%20Collection">Royal Philatelic Collection</a> into the most comprehensive collection of United Kingdom and Commonwealth stamps in the world, in some cases setting record purchase prices for items.
In October 1894, George's maternal uncle-by-marriage, <a href="Alexander%20III%20of%20Russia">Tsar Alexander III of Russia</a>, died. At the request of his father, "out of respect for poor dear Uncle Sasha's memory", George joined his parents in St Petersburg for the funeral. He and his parents remained in Russia for the wedding a week later of the new Russian emperor, his maternal first cousin <a href="Nicholas%20II">Nicholas II</a>, to one of George's paternal first cousins, <a href="Princess%20Alix%20of%20Hesse%20and%20by%20Rhine">Princess Alix of Hesse and by Rhine</a>, who had once been considered as a potential bride for George's elder brother.
Prince of Wales.
As Duke of York, George carried out a wide variety of public duties. On the death of Queen Victoria on 22 January 1901, George's father ascended the throne as <a href="King%20Edward%20VII">King Edward VII</a>. George inherited the title of <a href="Duke%20of%20Cornwall">Duke of Cornwall</a>, and for much of the rest of that year, he was known as the Duke of Cornwall and York.
In 1901, the Duke and Duchess toured the <a href="British%20Empire">British Empire</a>. Their tour included Gibraltar, Malta, Port Said, <a href="Aden">Aden</a>, Ceylon, <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a>, Australia, New Zealand, Mauritius, South Africa, Canada, and the <a href="Colony%20of%20Newfoundland">Colony of Newfoundland</a>. The tour was designed by <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20the%20Colonies">Colonial Secretary</a> <a href="Joseph%20Chamberlain">Joseph Chamberlain</a> with the support of Prime Minister <a href="Lord%20Salisbury">Lord Salisbury</a> to reward the Dominions for their participation in the <a href="South%20African%20War">South African War</a> of 1899–1902. George presented thousands of specially designed South African War medals to colonial troops. In South Africa, the royal party met civic leaders, African leaders, and Boer prisoners, and was greeted by elaborate decorations, expensive gifts, and fireworks displays. Despite this, not all residents responded favourably to the tour. Many white Cape <a href="Afrikaner">Afrikaner</a>s resented the display and expense, the war having weakened their capacity to reconcile their Afrikaner-Dutch culture with their status as British subjects. Critics in the English-language press decried the enormous cost at a time when families faced severe hardship.
In Australia, the Duke opened the first session of the <a href="Australian%20Parliament">Australian Parliament</a> upon the <a href="Constitutional%20history%20of%20Australia">creation of the Commonwealth of Australia</a>. In New Zealand, he praised the military values, bravery, loyalty, and obedience to duty of New Zealanders, and the tour gave New Zealand a chance to show off its progress, especially in its adoption of up-to-date British standards in communications and the processing industries. The implicit goal was to advertise New Zealand's attractiveness to tourists and potential immigrants, while avoiding news of growing social tensions, by focusing the attention of the British press on a land few knew about. On his return to Britain, in a speech at <a href="Guildhall%2C%20London">Guildhall, London</a>, George warned of "the impression which seemed to prevail among [our] brethren across the seas, that the Old Country must wake up if she intends to maintain her old position of pre-eminence in her colonial trade against foreign competitors."
On 9 November 1901, George was created <a href="Prince%20of%20Wales">Prince of Wales</a> and <a href="Earl%20of%20Chester">Earl of Chester</a>. King Edward wished to prepare his son for his future role as king. In contrast to Edward himself, whom Queen Victoria had deliberately excluded from state affairs, George was given wide access to state documents by his father. George in turn allowed his wife access to his papers, as he valued her counsel and she often helped write her husband's speeches. As Prince of Wales, he supported reforms in naval training, including cadets being enrolled at the ages of twelve and thirteen, and receiving the same education, whatever their class and eventual assignments. The reforms were implemented by the then Second (later First) Sea Lord, <a href="Sir%20John%20Fisher">Sir John Fisher</a>.
From November 1905 to March 1906, George and May toured <a href="British%20India">British India</a>, where he was disgusted by racial discrimination and campaigned for greater involvement of Indians in the government of the country. The tour was almost immediately followed by a trip to Spain for the wedding of <a href="King%20Alfonso%20XIII">King Alfonso XIII</a> to <a href="Victoria%20Eugenie%20of%20Battenberg">Victoria Eugenie of Battenberg</a>, a first cousin of George, at which the bride and groom narrowly avoided assassination. A week after returning to Britain, George and May travelled to <a href="Norway">Norway</a> for the <a href="Coronations%20in%20Norway">coronation</a> of <a href="King%20Haakon%20VII">King Haakon VII</a>, George's cousin and brother-in-law, and <a href="Maud%20of%20Wales">Queen Maud</a>, George's sister.
King and emperor.
On 6 May 1910, Edward VII died, and George became king. He wrote in his diary,
George had never liked his wife's habit of signing official documents and letters as "Victoria Mary" and insisted she drop one of those names. They both thought she should not be called Queen Victoria, and so she became Queen Mary. Later that year, a radical propagandist, <a href="Edward%20Mylius">Edward Mylius</a>, published a lie that George had secretly married in Malta as a young man, and that consequently his marriage to Queen Mary was bigamous. The lie had first surfaced in print in 1893, but George had shrugged it off as a joke. In an effort to kill off rumours, Mylius was arrested, tried and found guilty of <a href="criminal%20libel">criminal libel</a>, and was sentenced to a year in prison.
George objected to the <a href="anti-Catholic">anti-Catholic</a> wording of the Accession Declaration that he would be required to make at the opening of his first parliament. He made it known that he would refuse to open parliament unless it was changed. As a result, the <a href="Accession%20Declaration%20Act%201910">Accession Declaration Act 1910</a> shortened the declaration and removed the most offensive phrases.
<a href="Coronation%20of%20George%20V%20and%20Mary">George and Mary's coronation</a> took place at <a href="Westminster%20Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a> on 22 June 1911, and was celebrated by the <a href="Festival%20of%20Empire">Festival of Empire</a> in London. In July, the King and Queen visited <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a> for five days; they received a warm welcome, with thousands of people lining the route of their procession to cheer.
Later in 1911, the King and Queen travelled to India for the <a href="Delhi%20Durbar%23Durbar%20of%201911">Delhi Durbar</a>, where they were presented to an assembled audience of Indian dignitaries and princes as the <a href="Emperor%20and%20Empress%20of%20India">Emperor and Empress of India</a> on 12 December 1911. George wore the newly created <a href="Imperial%20Crown%20of%20India">Imperial Crown of India</a> at the ceremony, and declared the shifting of the Indian capital from <a href="Calcutta">Calcutta</a> to <a href="Delhi">Delhi</a>. He was the only Emperor of India to be present at his own Delhi Durbar.
They travelled throughout the subcontinent, and George took the opportunity to indulge in <a href="1911%20George%20V%20hunting%20in%20Nepal">big game hunting in Nepal</a>, shooting 21 tigers, 8 rhinoceroses and a bear over 10 days. He was a keen and expert marksman. On 18 December 1913, he shot over a thousand <a href="pheasant">pheasant</a>s in six hours at <a href="Hall%20Barn">Hall Barn</a>, the home of <a href="Edward%20Levy-Lawson%2C%201st%20Baron%20Burnham">Lord Burnham</a>, although even George had to acknowledge that "we went a little too far" that day.
National politics.
George inherited the throne at a politically turbulent time. <a href="Lloyd%20George">Lloyd George</a>'s <a href="People%27s%20Budget">People's Budget</a> had been rejected the previous year by the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative</a> and <a href="Unionism%20in%20Ireland">Unionist</a>-dominated <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a>, contrary to the normal convention that the Lords did not veto <a href="money%20bill">money bill</a>s. <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28UK%29">Liberal</a> Prime Minister <a href="H.%20H.%20Asquith">H. H. Asquith</a> had asked the previous king to give an undertaking that he would create sufficient Liberal peers to force the budget through the House. Edward had reluctantly agreed, provided the Lords rejected the budget after two successive general elections. After the <a href="January%201910%20general%20election">January 1910 general election</a>, the Conservative peers allowed the budget, for which the government now had an electoral mandate, to pass without a vote.
Asquith attempted to curtail the power of the Lords through constitutional reforms, which were again blocked by the Upper House. A constitutional conference on the reforms broke down in November 1910 after 21 meetings. Asquith and <a href="Robert%20Crewe-Milnes%2C%201st%20Marquess%20of%20Crewe">Lord Crewe</a>, Liberal leader in the Lords, asked George to grant a dissolution, leading to a second general election, and to promise to create sufficient Liberal peers if the Lords blocked the legislation again. If George refused, the Liberal government would otherwise resign, which would have given the appearance that the monarch was taking sides—with "the peers against the people"—in party politics. The King's two private secretaries, the Liberal <a href="Francis%20Knollys%2C%201st%20Viscount%20Knollys">Lord Knollys</a> and the Unionist <a href="Lord%20Stamfordham">Lord Stamfordham</a>, gave George conflicting advice. Knollys advised George to accept the Cabinet's demands, while Stamfordham advised George to accept the resignation. Like his father, George reluctantly agreed to the dissolution and creation of peers, although he felt his ministers had taken advantage of his inexperience to browbeat him. After the <a href="December%201910%20general%20election">December 1910 general election</a>, the Lords let the bill pass on hearing of the threat to swamp the house with new peers. The subsequent <a href="Parliament%20Act%201911">Parliament Act 1911</a> permanently removed—with a few exceptions—the power of the Lords to veto bills. The King later came to feel that Knollys had withheld information from him about the willingness of the opposition to form a government if the Liberals had resigned.
The 1910 general elections had left the Liberals as a minority government dependent upon the support of the <a href="Irish%20Nationalist%20Party">Irish Nationalist Party</a>. As desired by the Nationalists, Asquith introduced <a href="Home%20Rule%20Act%201914">legislation that would give Ireland Home Rule</a>, but the Conservatives and Unionists opposed it. As tempers rose over the Home Rule Bill, which would never have been possible without the Parliament Act, relations between the elderly Knollys and the Conservatives became poor, and he was pushed into retirement. Desperate to avoid the prospect of civil war in Ireland between Unionists and Nationalists, George called a <a href="Buckingham%20Palace%20Conference">meeting of all parties at Buckingham Palace</a> in July 1914 in an attempt to negotiate a settlement. After four days the conference ended without an agreement. Political developments in Britain and Ireland were overtaken by events in Europe, and the issue of Irish Home Rule was <a href="Suspensory%20Act%201914">suspended</a> for the duration of the war.
First World War.
On 4 August 1914, the King wrote in his diary, "I held a council at 10.45 to declare war with Germany. It is a terrible catastrophe but it is not our fault. ... Please to God it may soon be over." From 1914 to 1918, <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20I">Britain and its allies</a> were at <a href="World%20War%20I">war</a> with the <a href="Central%20Powers">Central Powers</a>, led by the <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a>. The German Kaiser <a href="Wilhelm%20II">Wilhelm II</a>, who for the British public came to symbolise all the horrors of the war, was the King's first cousin. The King's paternal grandfather was <a href="Prince%20Albert%20of%20Saxe-Coburg%20and%20Gotha">Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha</a>; consequently, the King and his children bore the German titles Prince and Princess of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha and Duke and Duchess of Saxony. Queen Mary, although born in England like her mother, was the daughter of the <a href="Francis%2C%20Duke%20of%20Teck">Duke of Teck</a>, a descendant of the German <a href="Dukes%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg">Dukes of Württemberg</a>. The King had brothers-in-law and cousins who were British subjects but who bore German titles such as Duke and Duchess of Teck, Prince and Princess of Battenberg, and Prince and Princess of Schleswig-Holstein. When <a href="H.%20G.%20Wells">H. G. Wells</a> wrote about Britain's "alien and uninspiring court", George replied: "I may be uninspiring, but I'll be damned if I'm alien."
On 17 July 1917, George appeased British nationalist feelings by issuing a royal proclamation that changed the name of the British <a href="royal%20house">royal house</a> from the German-sounding <a href="House%20of%20Saxe-Coburg%20and%20Gotha">House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha</a> to the <a href="House%20of%20Windsor">House of Windsor</a>. He and all his British relatives relinquished their German titles and styles and adopted British-sounding surnames. George compensated his male relatives by giving them British peerages. His cousin <a href="Prince%20Louis%20of%20Battenberg">Prince Louis of Battenberg</a>, who earlier in the war had been forced to resign as <a href="First%20Sea%20Lord">First Sea Lord</a> through anti-German feeling, became Louis Mountbatten, 1st Marquess of Milford Haven, while Queen Mary's brothers became <a href="Adolphus%20Cambridge%2C%201st%20Marquess%20of%20Cambridge">Adolphus Cambridge, 1st Marquess of Cambridge</a>, and <a href="Alexander%20Cambridge%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Athlone">Alexander Cambridge, 1st Earl of Athlone</a>.
In <a href="letters%20patent">letters patent</a> gazetted on 11 December 1917, the King restricted the style of "Royal Highness" and the titular dignity of "Prince (or Princess) of Great Britain and Ireland" to the children of the Sovereign, the children of the sons of the Sovereign and the eldest living son of the eldest son of a Prince of Wales. The letters patent also stated that "the titles of Royal Highness, Highness or Serene Highness, and the titular dignity of Prince and Princess shall cease except those titles already granted and remaining unrevoked". George's relatives who fought on the German side, such as <a href="Ernest%20Augustus%2C%20Crown%20Prince%20of%20Hanover">Ernest Augustus, Crown Prince of Hanover</a>, and <a href="Charles%20Edward%2C%20Duke%20of%20Saxe-Coburg%20and%20Gotha">Charles Edward, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha</a>, had their British peerages suspended by a 1919 <a href="Order%20in%20Council">Order in Council</a> under the provisions of the <a href="Titles%20Deprivation%20Act%201917">Titles Deprivation Act 1917</a>. Under pressure from his mother, Queen Alexandra, the King also removed the <a href="St%20George%27s%20Chapel%2C%20Windsor%20Castle%23Heraldry">Garter flags</a> of his German relations from <a href="St%20George%27s%20Chapel%2C%20Windsor%20Castle">St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle</a>.
When Tsar Nicholas II of Russia, George's first cousin, was overthrown in the <a href="Russian%20Revolution%20of%201917">Russian Revolution of 1917</a>, the British government offered <a href="political%20asylum">political asylum</a> to the Tsar and his family, but worsening conditions for the British people, and fears that revolution might come to the British Isles, led George to think that the presence of the <a href="Romanovs">Romanovs</a> would be seen as inappropriate. Despite the later claims of <a href="Lord%20Mountbatten%20of%20Burma">Lord Mountbatten of Burma</a> that Prime Minister <a href="David%20Lloyd%20George">David Lloyd George</a> was opposed to the rescue of the Russian imperial family, the letters of Lord Stamfordham suggest that it was George V who opposed the idea against the advice of the government. Advance planning for a rescue was undertaken by <a href="MI1">MI1</a>, a branch of the British secret service, but because of the strengthening position of the <a href="Bolshevik">Bolshevik</a> revolutionaries and wider difficulties with the conduct of the war, the plan was never put into operation. The Tsar and his immediate family remained in Russia, where they were <a href="Execution%20of%20the%20Romanov%20family">killed by the Bolsheviks in 1918</a>. George wrote in his diary: "It was a foul murder. I was devoted to Nicky, who was the kindest of men and thorough gentleman: loved his country and people." The following year, Nicholas's mother, <a href="Maria%20Feodorovna%20%28Dagmar%20of%20Denmark%29">Marie Feodorovna</a>, and other members of the extended Russian imperial family were rescued from <a href="Crimea">Crimea</a> by a British warship.
Two months after the end of the war, the King's youngest son, <a href="Prince%20John%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">John</a>, died at the age of 13 after a lifetime of ill health. George was informed of his death by Queen Mary, who wrote, "[John] had been a great anxiety to us for many years ... The first break in the family circle is hard to bear but people have been so kind & sympathetic & this has helped us much."
In May 1922, the King toured Belgium and northern France, visiting the First World War cemeteries and memorials being constructed by the <a href="Imperial%20War%20Graves%20Commission">Imperial War Graves Commission</a>. The event was described in a poem, "<a href="The%20King%27s%20Pilgrimage">The King's Pilgrimage</a>" by <a href="Rudyard%20Kipling">Rudyard Kipling</a>. The tour, and one short visit to Italy in 1923, were the only times George agreed to leave the United Kingdom on official business after the end of the war.
Post-war reign.
Before the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, most of Europe was ruled by monarchs related to George, but during and after the war, the monarchies of Austria, Germany, Greece, and Spain, like Russia, fell to revolution and war. In March 1919, Lieutenant-Colonel <a href="Edward%20Lisle%20Strutt">Edward Lisle Strutt</a> was dispatched on the personal authority of the King to escort the former Emperor <a href="Charles%20I%20of%20Austria">Charles I of Austria</a> and his family to safety in Switzerland. In 1922, a <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> ship was sent to Greece to rescue his cousins, <a href="Prince%20Andrew%20of%20Greece%20and%20Denmark">Prince</a> and <a href="Princess%20Andrew">Princess Andrew</a>.
Political turmoil in Ireland continued as the Nationalists <a href="Irish%20War%20of%20Independence">fought for independence</a>; George expressed his horror at government-sanctioned killings and reprisals to Prime Minister Lloyd George. At the opening session of the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Northern%20Ireland">Parliament of Northern Ireland</a> on 22 June 1921, the King appealed for conciliation in a speech part drafted by General <a href="Jan%20Smuts">Jan Smuts</a> and approved by Lloyd George. A few weeks later, a truce was agreed. Negotiations between Britain and the Irish secessionists led to the signing of the <a href="Anglo-Irish%20Treaty">Anglo-Irish Treaty</a>. By the end of 1922, <a href="Partition%20of%20Ireland">Ireland was partitioned</a>, the <a href="Irish%20Free%20State">Irish Free State</a> was established, and Lloyd George was out of office.
The King and his advisers were concerned about the rise of socialism and the growing labour movement, which they mistakenly associated with republicanism. The socialists no longer believed in their anti-monarchical slogans and were ready to come to terms with the monarchy if it took the first step. George adopted a more democratic, inclusive stance that crossed class lines and brought the monarchy closer to the public and the working class—a dramatic change for the King, who was most comfortable with naval officers and landed gentry. He cultivated friendly relations with moderate <a href="Labour%20Party%20%28UK%29">Labour Party</a> politicians and trade union officials. His abandonment of social aloofness conditioned the royal family's behaviour and enhanced its popularity during the economic crises of the 1920s and for over two generations thereafter.
The years between 1922 and 1929 saw frequent changes in government. In 1924, George appointed the first Labour Prime Minister, <a href="Ramsay%20MacDonald">Ramsay MacDonald</a>, in the absence of a clear majority for any one of the three major parties. George's tactful and understanding reception of the first Labour government (which lasted less than a year) allayed the suspicions of the party's sympathisers. During the <a href="General%20Strike%20of%201926">General Strike of 1926</a> the King advised the government of <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative</a> <a href="Stanley%20Baldwin">Stanley Baldwin</a> against taking inflammatory action, and took exception to suggestions that the strikers were "revolutionaries" saying, "Try living on their wages before you judge them."
In 1926, George hosted an <a href="Imperial%20Conference">Imperial Conference</a> in London at which the <a href="Balfour%20Declaration%20of%201926">Balfour Declaration</a> accepted the growth of the <a href="British%20Dominions">British Dominions</a> into self-governing "autonomous Communities within the British Empire, equal in status, in no way subordinate one to another". The <a href="Statute%20of%20Westminster%201931">Statute of Westminster 1931</a> formalised the Dominions' legislative independence and established that the succession to the throne could not be changed unless all the Parliaments of the Dominions as well as the Parliament at Westminster agreed. The Statute's preamble described the monarch as "the symbol of the free association of the members of the British Commonwealth of Nations", who were "united by a common allegiance".
In the wake of a <a href="Great%20Depression">world financial crisis</a>, the King encouraged the formation of a <a href="National%20Government%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">National Government</a> in 1931 led by MacDonald and Baldwin, and volunteered to reduce the <a href="civil%20list">civil list</a> to help balance the budget. He was concerned by the rise to power in <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Germany</a> of <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> and the <a href="Nazi%20Party">Nazi Party</a>. In 1934, the King bluntly told the German ambassador <a href="Leopold%20von%20Hoesch">Leopold von Hoesch</a> that Germany was now the peril of the world, and that there was bound to be a war within ten years if Germany went on at the present rate; he warned the British ambassador in Berlin, <a href="Eric%20Phipps">Eric Phipps</a>, to be suspicious of the Nazis.
In 1932, George agreed to deliver a <a href="Royal%20Christmas%20speech">Royal Christmas speech</a> on the radio, an event that became annual thereafter. He was not in favour of the innovation originally but was persuaded by the argument that it was what his people wanted. By the <a href="Silver%20Jubilee%20of%20George%20V">Silver Jubilee</a> of his reign in 1935, he had become a well-loved king, saying in response to the crowd's adulation, "I cannot understand it, after all I am only a very ordinary sort of fellow."
George's relationship with his eldest son and heir, <a href="Edward%20VIII">Edward</a>, deteriorated in these later years. George was disappointed in Edward's failure to settle down in life and appalled by his many affairs with married women. In contrast, he was fond of his second son, Prince Albert (later <a href="George%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BVI">George VI</a>), and doted on his eldest granddaughter, <a href="Elizabeth%20II">Princess Elizabeth</a>; he nicknamed her "Lilibet", and she affectionately called him "Grandpa England". In 1935, George said of his son Edward: "After I am dead, the boy will ruin himself within 12 months", and of Albert and Elizabeth: "I pray to God my eldest son will never marry and have children, and that nothing will come between Bertie and Lilibet and the throne."
Declining health and death.
The First World War took a toll on George's health: he was seriously injured on 28 October 1915 when thrown by his horse at a troop review in France, and his heavy smoking exacerbated recurring breathing problems. He suffered from <a href="chronic%20bronchitis">chronic bronchitis</a>. In 1925, on the instruction of his doctors, he was reluctantly sent on a recuperative private cruise in the Mediterranean; it was his third trip abroad since the war, and his last. In November 1928, he fell seriously ill with <a href="septicaemia">septicaemia</a>, and for the next two years his son Edward took over many of his duties. In 1929, the suggestion of a further rest abroad was rejected by the King "in rather strong language". Instead, he retired for three months to <a href="Craigweil%20House">Craigweil House</a>, <a href="Aldwick">Aldwick</a>, in the seaside resort of <a href="Bognor">Bognor</a>, <a href="West%20Sussex">Sussex</a>. As a result of his stay, the town acquired the suffix "Regis", which is Latin for "of the King". A myth later grew that his last words, upon being told that he would soon be well enough to revisit the town, were "Bugger Bognor!"
George never fully recovered. In his final year, he was occasionally administered oxygen. The death of his favourite sister, <a href="Princess%20Victoria%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Victoria</a>, in December 1935 depressed him deeply. On the evening of 15 January 1936, the King took to his bedroom at <a href="Sandringham%20House">Sandringham House</a> complaining of a cold; he remained in the room until his death. He became gradually weaker, drifting in and out of consciousness. Prime Minister Baldwin later said:
By 20 January, he was close to death. His physicians, led by <a href="Lord%20Dawson%20of%20Penn">Lord Dawson of Penn</a>, issued a bulletin with the words "The King's life is moving peacefully towards its close." Dawson's private diary, unearthed after his death and made public in 1986, reveals that the King's last words, a mumbled "God damn you!", were addressed to his nurse, <a href="Catherine%20Black%20%28nurse%29">Catherine Black</a>, when she gave him a sedative that night. Dawson, who supported the "gentle growth of <a href="euthanasia">euthanasia</a>", admitted in the diary that he hastened the King's death by injecting him, after 11:00 p.m., with two consecutive lethal injections: 3/4 of a <a href="Grain%20%28unit%29">grain</a> of <a href="morphine">morphine</a> followed shortly afterwards by a grain of <a href="cocaine">cocaine</a>. Dawson wrote that he acted to preserve the King's dignity, to prevent further strain on the family, and so that the King's death at 11:55 p.m. could be announced in the morning edition of "<a href="The%20Times">The Times</a>" newspaper rather than "less appropriate ... evening journals". Neither Queen Mary, who was intensely religious and might not have sanctioned euthanasia, nor the Prince of Wales was consulted. The royal family did not want the King to endure pain and suffering and did not want his life prolonged artificially but neither did they approve Dawson's actions. "<a href="British%20Path%C3%A9">British Pathé</a>" announced the King's death the following day, in which he was described as "for each one of us, more than a King, a father of a great family".
The German composer <a href="Paul%20Hindemith">Paul Hindemith</a> went to a BBC studio on the morning after the King's death and in six hours wrote "<a href="Trauermusik">Trauermusik</a>" (Mourning Music), for viola and orchestra. It was performed that same evening in a live broadcast by the BBC, with <a href="Adrian%20Boult">Adrian Boult</a> conducting the <a href="BBC%20Symphony%20Orchestra">BBC Symphony Orchestra</a> and the composer as soloist.
At the procession to George's <a href="lying%20in%20state">lying in state</a> in <a href="Westminster%20Hall">Westminster Hall</a>, the cross surmounting the <a href="Imperial%20State%20Crown">Imperial State Crown</a> atop George's coffin fell off and landed in the gutter as the cortège turned into <a href="New%20Palace%20Yard">New Palace Yard</a>. The new king, Edward VIII, saw it fall and wondered whether it was a bad omen for his new reign. As a mark of respect to their father, George's four surviving sons, Edward, Albert, <a href="Prince%20Henry%2C%20Duke%20of%20Gloucester">Henry</a>, and <a href="Prince%20George%2C%20Duke%20of%20Kent">George</a>, mounted the guard, known as the <a href="Vigil%20of%20the%20Princes">Vigil of the Princes</a>, at the <a href="catafalque">catafalque</a> on the night before the funeral. The vigil was not repeated until the death of George's daughter-in-law, <a href="Queen%20Elizabeth%20The%20Queen%20Mother">Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother</a>, in 2002. George V was interred at <a href="St%20George%27s%20Chapel%2C%20Windsor%20Castle">St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle</a>, on 28 January 1936. Edward abdicated before the year was out, leaving Albert to ascend the throne as George VI.
Legacy.
George V disliked sitting for portraits and despised <a href="modern%20art">modern art</a>; he was so displeased by one portrait by <a href="Charles%20Sims%20%28painter%29">Charles Sims</a> that he ordered it to be burned. He did admire sculptor <a href="Bertram%20Mackennal">Bertram Mackennal</a>, who created statues of George for display in Madras and Delhi, and <a href="William%20Reid%20Dick">William Reid Dick</a>, whose <a href="Statue%20of%20George%20V%2C%20Westminster">statue of George V</a> stands outside <a href="Westminster%20Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a>, London.
George preferred to stay at home pursuing his hobbies of <a href="stamp%20collecting">stamp collecting</a> and <a href="Hunting%20and%20shooting%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">game shooting</a>, and he lived a life that later biographers considered dull because of its conventionality. He was not an intellectual; on returning from one evening at the opera, he wrote in his journal, "Went to <a href="Covent%20Garden">Covent Garden</a> and saw "<a href="Fidelio">Fidelio</a>" and damned dull it was." Nonetheless, he was earnestly devoted to Britain and its Commonwealth. He explained, "it has always been my dream to identify myself with the great idea of Empire." He appeared hard-working and became widely admired by the people of Britain and the Empire, as well as "<a href="the%20Establishment">the Establishment</a>". In the words of historian <a href="David%20Cannadine">David Cannadine</a>, King George V and Queen Mary were an "inseparably devoted couple" who upheld "character" and "family values".
George established a standard of conduct for British royalty that reflected the values and virtues of the upper middle-class rather than upper-class lifestyles or vices. Acting within his constitutional bounds, he dealt skilfully with a succession of crises: Ireland, the First World War, and the first socialist minority government in Britain. He was by temperament a traditionalist who never fully appreciated or approved the revolutionary changes underway in British society. Nevertheless, he invariably wielded his influence as a force of neutrality and moderation, seeing his role as mediator rather than final decision-maker.
Titles, styles, honours and arms.
Titles and styles.
His full style as king was "George V, by the Grace of God, of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and of the British Dominions beyond the Seas, King, Defender of the Faith, Emperor of India" until the <a href="Royal%20and%20Parliamentary%20Titles%20Act%201927">Royal and Parliamentary Titles Act 1927</a>, when it changed to "George V, by the Grace of God, of Great Britain, Ireland and the British Dominions beyond the Seas, King, Defender of the Faith, Emperor of India".
British honours.
On 4 June 1917, he founded the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Order of the British Empire</a>.
Arms.
As Duke of York, George's arms were the <a href="Royal%20coat%20of%20arms%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">royal arms</a>, with an <a href="inescutcheon">inescutcheon</a> of the <a href="Coat%20of%20arms%20of%20Saxony">arms of Saxony</a>, all differenced with a <a href="Label%20%28heraldry%29">label</a> of three points <a href="argent">argent</a>, the centre point bearing an anchor <a href="Azure%20%28heraldry%29">azure</a>. The anchor was removed from his <a href="Coat%20of%20arms%20of%20the%20Prince%20of%20Wales">coat of arms as the Prince of Wales</a>. As King, he bore the royal arms. In 1917, he removed, by warrant, the Saxony inescutcheon from the arms of all male-line descendants of the Prince Consort domiciled in the United Kingdom (although the royal arms themselves had never borne the shield).
